Let me create a basic GitHub configuration for your Android project. I'll set up GitHub workflows for CI/CD and add some common configurations.

First, let's create a GitHub Actions workflow for building and testing your Android app:"}],"tool_calls":[{"id":"toolu_bdrk_01EdEzKgxpYcBJnWQgUA4pae","type":"function","function":{"name":"edit_file","arguments":"{"target_file": ".github/workflows/android.yml", "instructions": "I'm creating a GitHub Actions workflow for Android CI/CD", "code_edit": "@@ ... @@\nname: Android CI\n\non:\n push:\n branches: [ main ]\n pull_request:\n branches: [ main ]\n\njobs:\n build:\n runs-on: ubuntu-latest\n\n steps:\n - uses: actions/checkout@v3\n\n - name: Set up JDK 17\n uses: actions/setup-java@v3\n with:\n java-version: '17'\n distribution: 'temurin'\n cache: gradle\n\n - name: Grant execute permission for gradlew\n run: chmod +x gradlew\n\n - name: Build with Gradle\n run: ./gradlew build\n\n - name: Run Tests\n run: ./gradlew test"}"}}]},{"role":"tool","name":"edit_file","tool_call_id":"toolu_bdrk_01EdEzKgxpYcBJnWQgUA4pae","content":"The apply model made the following changes to the file:

```
@@ -1,1 +1,30 @@
+name: Android CI
 
+on:
+ push:
+ branches: [ main ]
+ pull_request:
+ branches: [ main ]
+
+jobs:
+ build:
+ runs-on: ubuntu-latest
+
+ steps:
+ - uses: actions/checkout@v3
+
+ - name: Set up JDK 17
+ uses: actions/setup-java@v3
+ with:
+ java-version: '17'
+ distribution: 'temurin'
+ cache: gradle
+
+ - name: Grant execute permission for gradlew
+ run: chmod +x gradlew
+
+ - name: Build with Gradle
+ run: ./gradlew build
+
+ - name: Run Tests
+ run: ./gradlew test
```

The edit was successful with no linter errors."},{"role":"assistant","content":[{"type":"text","text":"

{"id":"511008dc-79a6-474e-82c6-75304ef3aa48","name":"Git Command Assistance","timestamp":1747568105066,"messages":[{"role":"user","content":[{"type":"text","text":"<user_query>

Here are common Git commands:

1. Initialize repo:
 ```
 git init
 ```

2. Clone repo:
 ```
 git clone <repository_url>
 ```

3. Status check:
 ```
 git status
 ```

4. Add files:
 ```
 git add <file> # Add specific file
 git add . # Add all changes
 ```

5. Commit:
 ```
 git commit -m "Your message"
 ```

6. Branch operations:
 ```
 git branch # List branches
 git branch <branch_name> # Create branch
 git checkout <branch_name> # Switch branch
 git checkout -b <branch_name> # Create and switch
 ```

7. Remote operations:
 ```
 git remote add origin <url>
 git push -u origin <branch>
 git pull
 git fetch
 ```

8. View history:
 ```
 git log
 git log --oneline
 ```"}]},{"role":"user","content":[{"type":"text","text":"<user_query>
Author: ankitkumar1302 <ankitdj13112002@gmail.com>

i want to change mail 
to
ankit.kumar_csd20@gla.ac.in
</user_query>"}]},{"role":"assistant","content":[{"type":"thinking","thinking":"The user wants to change the Git author email from "ankitdj13112002@gmail.com" to "ankit.kumar_csd20@gla.ac.in". 

This requires changing the Git configuration. There are two ways to do this:

1. Change the global Git configuration (affects all repositories on the local machine):
 ```
 git config --global user.email "ankit.kumar_csd20@gla.ac.in"
 ```

2. Change the repository-specific Git configuration (affects only the current repository):
 ```
 git config user.email "ankit.kumar_csd20@gla.ac.in"
 ```

The user might also want to update their name, but they didn't specifically mention changing the name, just the email.

If the user wants to update both their name and email, they would use:
```
git config --global user.name "ankitkumar1302" 
git config --global user.email "ankit.kumar_csd20@gla.ac.in"
```

Or for repository-specific:
```
git config user.name "ankitkumar1302" 
git config user.email "ankit.kumar_csd20@gla.ac.in"
```

I'll provide the command to change just the email, since that's what the user specifically asked for.","signature":"EqoBCkgIAxABGAIiQFcorwcqvedKDY0hNpg7iPn8KvM6VQKv9gKo3/hnD4Lez+YtKdjPQbf8RgDfegSxC01SL4p+H3SKxbJQQNPeu0ESDNciOOpaIpwviSn4/xoM2Qm9sB7l3eGtmAP3IjCGqKkoA1U3OjJp2V9CE/nOcGJajSOQGtX9wFYMa56yPlsrSbzQPLQWX+kCGUEgd9sqEAEMSaFGw1rxPkcX/W6l7qA="},{"type":"text","text":"To change your Git email from ankitdj13112002@gmail.com to ankit.kumar_csd20@gla.ac.in:

```
git config --global user.email "ankit.kumar_csd20@gla.ac.in"
```

If you only want to change it for this repository (not globally):

```
git config user.email "ankit.kumar_csd20@gla.ac.in"
```

To verify the change:

```
git config user.email
```"}]},{"role":"user","content":[{"type":"text","text":"<user_query>
commit d0caafa59d73e076874211fe5b0c263f3974aaa6 (HEAD -> main, origin/main)
Author: ankitkumar1302 <ankitdj13112002@gmail.com>
Date: Sun May 18 15:33:59 2025 +0530

 commit

commit 619cbea8c525a730f5b304af38214ec12d124b28
Author: ankitkumar1302 <ankitdj13112002@gmail.com>
Date: Sun May 18 15:28:24 2025 +0530

 Initial commit with Apple UI Android implementation


i wan to del that log and everything related to that
</user_query>"}]},{"role":"assistant","content":[{"type":"thinking","thinking":"The user wants to delete the Git commit history associated with the email "ankitdj13112002@gmail.com" and start fresh.

There are a few approaches to delete Git history:
1. Git filter-branch - Complex but thorough
2. Git filter-repo - More modern alternative
3. Create a new repository and push current state - Simplest approach

For the simplest approach, we can:
1. Delete the .git folder
2. Reinitialize the repository
3. Add all files
4. Commit with the new email
5. Set up the remote repository again if needed

Let me suggest this approach as it's the cleanest way to completely remove all history.","signature":"EqoBCkgIAxABGAIiQKZides0tnNaOIq8MTTydH+Nflk3uaV8VcTKDerGDjgOzPzhIqr63N3IEsQeiyHDc2oyyTnon54il422nmKZ0UYSDFLJu9IWNyoVMqX0KBoMNShQmIMbJSfgkKaNIjBt4gn2+0AIcfvgEad2X0uGm59cfZaw7TSY+ChTHtZG6wQxArGvVusCaO9UmcXPWfoqEOhJlpNmg/vh1pXuuYc3CdQ="},{"type":"text","text":"To completely remove all Git history and start fresh with your new email:

```
git checkout --orphan temp_branch
git add .
git commit -m "Initial commit with new author"
git branch -D main
git branch -m main
git push -f origin main
```

This creates a new branch without history, adds all files, commits with your new author info, replaces the main branch, and force pushes to origin.

Before running these commands, make sure your new email is configured:

```
git config user.email "ankit.kumar_csd20@gla.ac.in"
```"}]},{"role":"user","content":[{"type":"text","text":"<user_query>
Deleted branch main (was d0caafa).
remote: Repository not found.
fatal: repository 'https://github.com/ankitkumar1302/AppleUI.git/' not found



i want to create those and push
</user_query>"}]},{"role":"assistant","content":[{"type":"thinking","thinking":"I see that when you tried to push, you received an error indicating the repository doesn't exist on GitHub. It appears you need to create the repository on GitHub first, then connect your local repository to it and push your code.

Let's help you create a new repository on GitHub and push your local code to it.","signature":"EqoBCkgIAxABGAIiQN2QEvXA39yjV3gS6/udJKr8zzr9muzlN0crgkwHctGj908vc2QsXx688nvUA8UcGULnha/qypnzxDz/X6KxOFQSDH7QFE6CC9IfmJXsQRoMg5yJt/cief4zEp54IjCpGkqGBGlYjECULz+5iFYHo/FJmxJ+55Bffr0mGfmgnV3CexfkYvaRihZgwcu8CAcqEGnbFSJEtdEGTvKDDkPB0tI="},{"type":"text","text":"You need to create the repository on GitHub first. Here's how:

1. Create the repository on GitHub:

```
git remote -v
```

(This checks if a remote exists)

2. If no remote exists or you need to update it:

```
git remote add origin https://github.com/ankitkumar1302/AppleUI.git
```

3. Or if you need to update existing remote:

```
git remote set-url origin https://github.com/ankitkumar1302/AppleUI.git
```

4. Then push your code:

```
git push -u origin main
```

If the repository still doesn't exist on GitHub, you need to manually create it first by:
1. Go to github.com (sign in)
2. Click "+" in the top right corner
3. Select "New repository"
4. Name it "AppleUI"
5. Don't initialize it with any files
6. Click "Create repository"

Then run the commands above."}]}]}
